natural problem: Find the greatest common divisor of $3339$, $2961$, and $1491$.
natural solution: We can perform the Euclidean Algorithm two times. First, we use it for $3339$ and $2961$. \begin{align} \text{gcd}\,(3339,2961) &=\text{gcd}\,(3339-2961,2961)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(378,2961)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(378,2961-378 \cdot 7)\\

&=\text{gcd}\,(378,315)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(378-315,315)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(63,315)\\ \end{align}Since $63$ is a divisor of $315$, the greatest common divisor of $3339$ and $2961$ is $63$. Next, we can find the greatest common divisor of $63$ and $1491$, also using the Euclidean Algorithm.
\begin{align} \text{gcd}\,(63,1491) &=\text{gcd}\,(63,1491-63 \cdot 23)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(63,42)\\ \end{align}Since $63=3 \cdot 21$ and $42=2 \cdot 21$, the greatest common divisor is $\boxed{21}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a = 3339"
and h1 : "b = 2961"
and h2 : "c = 1491"
shows  "gcd (gcd a b) c = 21"
a_0.formal solution:

 Find the greatest common divisor of $3339$, $2961$, and $1491$. The final Answer is 21
 ### Proof
 We can perform the Euclidean Algorithm two times. First, we use it for $3339$ and $2961$. \begin{align} \text{gcd}\,(3339,2961) &=\text{gcd}\,(3339-2961,2961)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(378,2961)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(378,2961-378 \cdot 7)\\
 &=\text{gcd}\,(378,315)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(378-315,315)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(63,315)\\ \end{align}Since $63$ is a divisor of $315$, the greatest common divisor of $3339$ and $2961$ is $63$. Next, we can find the greatest common divisor of $63$ and $1491$, also using the Euclidean Algorithm.
 \begin{align} \text{gcd}\,(63,1491) &=\text{gcd}\,(63,1491-63 \cdot 23)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(63,42)\\ \end{align}Since $63=3 \cdot 21$ and $42=2 \cdot 21$, the greatest common divisor is $\boxed{21}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: int
assumes h0 : "a = 3339"
and h1 : "b = 2961"
and h2 : "c = 1491"
shows  "gcd (gcd a b) c = 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

 \begin{align} \text{gcd}\,(63,1491) &=\text{gcd}\,(63,1491-63 \cdot 23)\\ &=\text{gcd}\,(63,42)\\ \end{align}Since $63=3 \cdot 21$ and $42=2 \cdot 21$, the greatest common divisor is $\boxed{21}$.
 *)
